task.title: How-to synchronize OxygenXML DITA files to GitHub
task.shortdesc: This is my verified procedure for synchronizing an OxygenXML DITA Project to GitHub. It is quite unintuitive but I found this is the most effective procedure. IMPORTANT: When creating your OxygenXML Project it is very important that you first organise your folders. Your DITA files must be loacted within the relevant folder. Also, any images or videos must be within the same Project folder. Do not use the dedicated folder for additional Projects and certainly do not move folders once set up. Finally, when creating new files in OxygenXML, ensure they are located within the relevant folder and have easy-to-remember file names.

taskbody.context: First create a GitHub reposoitory, then upload files, and finally synchronize from OxygenXML.

step.cmd: Create a new account at GitHub.com
Create a new repository. Click the green New icon in the top left corner of the webpage.
Name your Repository. You are advised to keep it short and memorable.
Type a short description of the intended content. This will help you and others recall the content as you create more repositories in future.
Select Public.
Select Add a README file.
Select Create repository.
You have successfully created a new repository.

task.title: How-to Add files to your repository.

step.cmd: In your GitHub repository, select Add file.
From the drop-down menu, selct Upload files.
Select choose your files.
Locate the relevent OxygenXML Project folder on your computer and select all the files.
Click the green icon Commit changes. In this instance, Commit directly to the main branch.
Your OxygenXML Project is now on GitHub.

task.title: How to synch Oxygen XML files to your GitHub repository.

step.cmd: In OxygenXML click the Git drop down menu and select Show staging
You will need to make changes to a DITA file such as adding text.
Save the file, and the file will appear in the Unstaged files pane of Git Staging.
Click the Stage all icon (two arrows facing downwards). The file will then move to the Staged files pane.
Type a short message in the Commit message pane. This is used to remind you of the edits you made.
The Commit button is now visible (not greyed out).
Click the Commit button.
Finally, at the top of the Git Staging panes, click the Push arrow (it is facing upwards) to push tyour changes to your GitHub repository.
You have successfully synchronized your OxygenXML Project to GitHub.
From this point onwards, you only need to use Git Staging after you have made changes in your OxyGenXML Project.
